item.title: 8 Biggest Lingering Questions In RPG History
item.description:
Summary

  • Many RPGs leave unanswered questions for fans to explore in future games or theories.
  • The lore of RPGs like The Elder Scrolls, Witcher, and Dragon Age is rich with mysteries.
  • Games like Undertale, Elden Ring, and Dark Souls have significant unresolved story elements.

RPGs tend to have massive stories full of quests and brimming with plotlines. Naturally, it's hard for every single idea to be wrapped up properly, and many game devs specifically leave open threads to explore in later games, or just to torture their poor fans.

Whether it's mysterious undiscovered lands or the identity and motivations of key unseen characters, RPGs have loads of unanswered questions worth investigating. This list is ranked by just how important the answers to the questions are.

8 What Is Akavir? - The Elder Scrolls

A Land Of Serpents?

Every single The Elder Scrolls game takes place in the land of Tamriel, whether in the idyllic plains of Cyrodiil or the blasted tundras of Skyrim. It's a well defined land full of in-depth lore, explored throughout the series, and particularly in The Elder Scrolls: Online .

However, Akavir has remained one of the series' biggest mysteries. This mysterious land far to the East is theorized to be The Elder Scrolls equivalent of East Asia, but what little documents survive conflict with each other and provide little detail. It is a land of snake-people martial arts masters? Hopefully one day fans will find out.

7 What Happened To The Other Witcher Schools? - The Witcher

A Lone Wolf

As a dark fantasy game, The Witcher games try to be as realistic as possible and generally follow a world in decline rather than at peak prosperity. That means for the titular Witcher Geralt, his people have been decimated. In the old days, there would have been hundreds of witchers, but at the time of the games, it's easy enough to count the living witchers on two hands.

However, there's lots of evidence of other Witcher schools that prospered in times past, yet it's never explained exactly what happened to many of them, only leaving behind their badass gear. This feels like an area ripe for exploration in the upcoming Witcher 4 , and one fans are eager to explore.

6 How Was The Blight Born? - Dragon Age

The Darkspawn's Origin

From the very beginning of Dragon Age: Origins , the Darkspawn have been one of the biggest enemies every protagonist faces on their adventures. These zombie-like blighted creatures arrive in cycles and wreak utter devastation before being beaten back, but no one really knows why or how this process works.

Even now, many games deep into the franchise, lore theorists still don't exactly know how the Darkspawn first came to be. Does it have something to do with the Maker and Andraste? Perhaps it's a punishment from demons beyond the Veil? No matter what happens next for the Dragon Age franchise, this remains one of the big questions for the theorists.

5 What Happened To W.D. Gaster? - Undertale

The Mastermind

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Undertale
RPG
Systems
10
9.6 /10
Released
September 15, 2015
ESRB
E10+ for Everyone 10+: Fantasy Violence, Mild Blood, Mild Language, Simulated Gambling, Use of Tobacco
Developer(s)
Toby Fox
Publisher(s)
Toby Fox, 8-4

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

On its surface, Undertale seems like a harmless little game, but any fan knows that the lore of Undertale 's world isn't just extensive, but riddled with mysteries that remain unanswered to this day, popularising a lot of wild fan theories.

The biggest unanswered mystery is who exactly W.D. Gaster, the royal scientist, was, and what happened to him? He's an incredibly important figure in the lore, and players are only able to interact with a strange ghostly sprite that many think is him. Did he die in an experiment? How does that relate to the world of Undertale players find? Hopefully, theorists will get answers one day.

4 What Exactly Are The Outer Gods—And How Many Are There? - Elden Ring

The Greater Will

6 Images
6 Images

Your comment has not been saved

Follow
Followed
Elden Ring
RPG
Action
Systems
10 /10
63
9.1 /10
Released
February 25, 2022
ESRB
M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Language, Suggestive Themes, Violence
Developer(s)
From Software
Publisher(s)
Bandai Namco Entertainment, From Software

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

Powered by

Every FromSoftware game deals in obscurity and vagueness with its lore as an intentional choice. Every game allows a variety of interpretations because FromSoftware refuses to be definitive about anything, leading to entire YouTube channels dedicated to unraveling the mysteries.

In Elden Ring , the most mysterious entities are the Outer Gods, of which the Greater Will, the current God in favor in The Lands Between, is part of. What role do these Gods play, do they combat with each other, why do they need champions, and why are they bound to the Elden Ring? Players are unlikely to get answers to these questions, which is a shame considering how influential they are over the game's lore.

3 What Caused The Great War? - Fallout

Dropping The Nukes

Fallout is defined by its post-apocalyptic world, but for a game so concerned with what happens to society after the end and the effect of radiation in the world, The Great War itself, the event that led to the dropping of the nukes, is surprisingly vague in detail.

Most crucial of all, theorists constantly debate whether the Americans or the Chinese dropped the bomb first, and what might have caused that final doomsday button to be pressed. There are clues throughout the games, but the truth is no one really knows.

2 What Happened To The Dwemer? - The Elder Scrolls

The Missing Dwarves

The world of Tamriel is rich with different species with different cultures, all contributing something magical to the world, but there are also fallen races, too, ancient peoples whose legacy dots the landscape, but mystery abounds about their true intent and demise.

In The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim , the Dwemer are the big mystery and the subject of a lot of lore. These genius subterranean Elves (who some think are the game's version of Dwarves) built incredible machines and underground brass cities, yet completely disappeared for unknown reasons. It's a tantalising thread that remains unpulled.

1 Who Is Gwyn's Firstborn? - Dark Souls

The Prodigal Son

Though Dark Souls wasn't the first Souls game ( Demon's Souls has that honor), it set the template for a lot of what was to come, including the deeply entrenched mysteries that wouldn't be discovered for years after release. In the original Dark Souls , that comes in the form of Gwyn's Firstborn Son, the so-called God of War.

Answers aren't provided for who this is, and most players only have a destroyed statue to work from to determine the identity. Many players think it might be The Nameless King from Dark Souls 3 , while others think the beloved Solaire might be the wayward son. It's unlikely players will ever know for certain.

item.title: Grow a Garden: All Bizzy Bear Crafter Recipes and Rewards
item.description:
Grow a Garden 's Bizzier Bees update added a number of new features and mechanics to the game. One of the more exciting additions is Bizzy Bear's Honey Crafter, which can be found just to the right of the Queen Bee in the center of the map. Providing Bizzy Bear with the right ingredients will reward Roblox players with all sorts of useful items, including new seeds and eggs. This includes Honeysuckle seeds, which sell for around 95,000 Sheckles once fully grown.

To complete a recipe, players will simply need to place honey in the barrel to Bizzy Bear's left and pollinated plants in the one to the right. After players have completed all 30 Bizzy Bear recipes, the Honey Crafter will reset, allowing players to claim all of the rewards again. Roblox players can find all of the seeds that they'll need in the shop, although can spend 39 Robux to skip a recipe if they're having trouble getting hold of some of the more elusive ones.

item.title: Dune Awakening: How To Fast Travel
item.description:
Dune: Awakening features a gigantic map divided into different biomes that players will gradually visit as they progress their character. One of the early means of transportation through the Sandworm-infested dunes of Arrakis is either by foot or with the Sandbike. However, this can often be quite risky as you're one Sandworm chomp away from losing everything in your inventory. So, players should make use of the fast travel service within the game offered by the Ornithopter Pilot.

Where to Find the Ornithopter Pilot for Fast Travel in Dune Awakening

Players can fast travel in Dune Awakening using the dedicated Taxi Service offered by the Omnithopter Pilot . The Omnithopter Pilot can be found within major cities and tradeposts, and will be able to take you from one location to another for some Solari (currency).

In the early game, you can find the Omnithopter Pilot inside the Griffin's Reach base , which is the first major tradepost you'll visit. The location is in the Hagga Basin South, just up the cliff that's illuminated by spotlights at night. Once you approach the tower, head inside, and you'll spot a pilot standing beside a hologram of an Ornithopter. Talk to the pilot, and you'll unlock the Taxi Service for fast travel in Dune Awakening .

Players will need to pay 2,500 Solari to fast travel to maps outside the Hagga Basin, and 700 Solari ​​​​​​if they need to simply travel to another tadepost or city from another biome (within the Hagga Basin).

How to Unlock More Fast Travel Points?

After choosing the " I want you to fly me somewhere " dialog option, you'll first have to select the region/areas where you need to travel. These regions include Hagga Basin, Arrakeen, and the Harko Village. Once the region is selected, choose the specific tradepost or city to fast travel to within said region.

At the beginning, there wouldn't be many locations available for you to fast travel. This is because you'll need to visit the tradeposts and cities in a region first before they're unlocked as fast travel points in Dune Awakening . Once you progress through the game enough and discover other tradeposts, those locations will be added as fast travel points to the Taxi Service menu.

item.title: Dungeons and Dragons' Unearthed Arcana Psion Class Explained
item.description:
Psionics are nothing new to Dungeons and Dragons . Creatures like mind flayers and subclasses such as Aberrant Mind Sorcerer, Soul Knife Rogue, and Psi Warrior Fighter all use psionics to some degree. However, there has never been an entire class built around psionics in 5th edition. Unearthed Arcana has just released an early version of the Psion class for Dungeons and Dragons , the first new class since the Artificer's release years ago.

Psions unleash the power of their mind on the world, to beneficial and devastating effect in turn. The new class has potential as a full spellcaster but, as it's a new Unearthed Arcana, there are some parts of the class that are lacking. An example is the Psion subclass, Telepathic Hub, which allows a Telepath to only telepathically communicate with a creature within 10 feet, while a Soulknife Rogue's range is 1 mile. Despite these limitations, the Psion is an interesting new class and has some exciting subclasses for players to explore.

Introducing a Brand New Dungeons and Dragons Class

As Unearthed Arcana, the Psion class features and mechanics are not yet final, and are likely to change if it's made official. Like other Dungeons and Dragons classes, the Psion class includes four subclasses that use psionics in different ways. As Psions regard psionics as magic, it is considered a full spellcaster. Like the Wizard class, Psions use Intelligence as their spellcasting ability, while Intelligence and Wisdom are the Psion's saving throw proficiencies. Like the Soulknife Rogue and Psi Warrior Fighter, the Psion's different psionic features outside of cantrips and spellcasting are determined by psionic dice and their rolls.

One major difference between Psions and other spellcasters is that they can cast spells without verbal or material components required, unless the components are destroyed when casting the spell. This means that Psions can cast a range of spells even when Silenced. Psions can also shift between two Modes from level 2: Attack Mode, which causes damage from the Psion's weapon attacks, Psion spells, and Psion features to ignore resistance to psychic damage; and Defense Mode, which grants resistance to psychic damage and the ability to add a psionic die to failed Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

Psions gain their subclass at level 3. The subclasses for Psion are:

  • Metamorph
  • Psi Warper
  • Psykinetic
  • Telepath

Metamorphs can use the power of their minds to shape their bodies, allowing them to morph their limbs into Organic Weapons and cast better healing spells. Psi Warpers can teleport themselves and their allies, as well as manipulate space. Psykinetics can harness telekinesis to create shields, fly, and hit their enemies with force. Telepaths can invade the minds of others, or use their abilities to rally their allies.

Psion Includes New Spells and Feats

The Psion spell list includes spells from Tasha's Cauldron of Everything in addition to two new spells and one new cantrip. New spells that Psions can use are Summon Astral Entity and Telekinetic Crush, while the new cantrip is Telekinetic Fling. Summon Astral Entity summons the spirit of a psionic creature, and uses the new Psionic Spirit stat block. Telekinetic Crush crushes all creatures in a 30-foot cube using force damage, and requires a Strength saving throw. Telekinetic Fling uses material components, where the material, enhanced by telekinetic power, is launched at a creature. The creature takes 1d10 force damage on a hit.

Psions also come with ten new feats that form the new Wild Talent category. These feats are designed to support the Psion spell list and enhance damage, healing, and Ability checks. As the effects of each Wild Talent are potent, players can only choose one Wild Talent.

The feats included as Wild Talents are:

  • Atmokinesis
  • Biokinesis
  • Clairsentience
  • Cryokinesis
  • Empath
  • Flesh Morpher
  • Mind Whisperer
  • Psi Trickster
  • Psykineticist
  • Pyrokinesis

Most of these feats involve changing the type of damage that the character deals when attacking, using their Intelligence modifier to improve Ability checks, or using a more limited version of other Psion subclass abilities.

item.title: 7 Best Co-Op Games That Are Instantly Fun, Ranked
item.description:
Summary

  • 'LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga' offers instant fun with seamless split-screen co-op and diverse gameplay.
  • 'Castle Crashers' delivers fast, chaotic, replayable action with unique characters and RPG elements.
  • 'It Takes Two' is an inventive, satisfying, and emotional co-op ride with constantly evolving mechanics.

Some co-op games take a few hours to click. Others expect everyone to memorize mechanics, micromanage resources, or — worst of all — get along. But a rare few feel electric from the first button press. There's no awkward onboarding, no long tutorials, no “trust-building exercises” before the good stuff starts.

These are the kinds of games that instantly turn two people on a couch into a howling, laughing mess. They don't hesitate to get straight to the fun, and stay there once things get going. Here are the best co-op games that don’t waste a second before getting fun.

7 LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga

9 Movies, 2 Jedi, 1 Couch

LEGO Star Wars: The Skywalker Saga
8 /10
8.7 /10
Released
April 5, 2022

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ for Everyone 10+: Cartoon Violence, Comic Mischief
Developer(s)
Traveller's Tales
Publisher(s)
Warner Bros. Games
Platform(s)
Switch, PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S
Powered by

At this point, LEGO games have the co-op formula perfected, but The Skywalker Saga pushes it into hyperspace. Covering all nine mainline Star Wars films in one giant package, the game lets players drop into any episode and instantly start smashing bricks, collecting studs, and force-yeeting stormtroopers into oblivion.

The split-screen co-op is seamless, letting players explore different parts of a level or galaxy without tethering them together. It’s fast, forgiving, and packed with enough content to keep a duo busy for months. But what makes it instantly fun is the sheer volume of things to do. One minute, players are chasing General Grievous through Utapau; the next, they're riding a bantha on Tatooine while slapping Jawas.

It’s also absurdly polished. Characters have unique abilities based on class, the combat is more fluid than any LEGO title before it, and the irreverent humor is dialed up without feeling overdone. Whether someone’s a lifelong Star Wars fan or just wants to punch sand people with Chewbacca, it clicks right away.

6 Castle Crashers

Four Knights, One Brain Cell

Castle Crashers
8 /10
8.8 /10
Released
August 27, 2008

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood and Gore, Cartoon Violence, Crude Humor
Developer(s)
The Behemoth
Publisher(s)
The Behemoth
Platform(s)
PC, PS3, Xbox 360
Powered by

The best co-op games don’t always need elaborate mechanics or sprawling narratives. Sometimes, all it takes is four tiny knights, a cartoonish art style, and the ability to knock a friend off their dinosaur with a fish. Castle Crashers is peak couch co-op: fast, chaotic, and endlessly replayable. It throws players into side-scrolling beat-em-up mayhem, full of boss fights, hordes of enemies, and weird surprises like alien ships and deer that rocket forward using projectile poop. Each character has their own elemental magic and stats, giving the experience a light RPG flavor without slowing down the action.

What makes it so immediately fun is its pace. Within seconds, players are button-mashing through enemies, grabbing loot, and fighting each other to win the affection of princesses in post-boss duels. It's pure arcade joy with a healthy dose of absurdity.

5 It Takes Two

Love, Divorce, And A Talking Book

6 Images
6 Images
It Takes Two
12
9.2 /10
Released
March 26, 2021

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Animated Blood, Comic Mischief, Fantasy Violence, Language
Developer(s)
Hazelight Studios
Publisher(s)
Electronic Arts
Platform(s)
PS4, PS5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, PC, Switch
Powered by

It Takes Two is the definitive co-op game. From the moment players pick up the controllers, they’re dropped into a whirlwind of genre shifts, puzzle-solving, and emotional whiplash, all packaged inside a story about a couple on the brink of divorce, magically turned into dolls.

Every level introduces something brand new. First, players are shrinking and growing in a clock tower, then they're using magnets to traverse a snowy village. The mechanics never repeat, and both players always have different abilities that require actual teamwork, not just taking turns. There’s humor, heartbreak, and more than a few WTF moments — like when the couple tears apart a stuffed elephant in one of the darkest sequences ever included in a family-friendly game. Josef Fares’ vision of two people healing through chaos translates into one of the most inventive and satisfying co-op rides of all time.

4 Moving Out

We Broke The Sink Again

Moving Out
Puzzle
Action
Systems
Released
April 28, 2020

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E For Everyone // Mild Cartoon Violence
Developer(s)
Devm Games
Publisher(s)
SMG Studio
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
Powered by

There’s something satisfying about breaking every piece of furniture in a client’s house and still getting paid. Moving Out turns the soul-numbing task of relocating boxes into a slapstick, physics-based comedy routine where success is optional and style is everything.

Players take on the role of “furniture arrangement technicians,” which mostly involves flinging sofas through windows and watching someone miss the truck entirely. Objects have real weight and momentum, which means heavier items need teamwork — or creative solutions involving trampolines and broken glass.

There’s no right way to complete a level. Some players play smart, using clean exits and careful turns. Others lob microwaves across swimming pools and pray for a miracle. The game rewards both equally, which is part of its genius. It’s fun from the first couch toss, and even more fun when everything goes wrong.

3 Cuphead

Soul-Crushing Difficulty Never Looked So Charming

Cuphead
9 /10
8.7 /10
Released
September 29, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ for Everyone 10+: Fantasy Violence, Mild Language, Use of Alcohol and Tobacco
Developer(s)
Studio MDHR Entertainment Inc.
Publisher(s)
Studio MDHR Entertainment Inc.
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, Switch, PC
Powered by

It’s wild how something that looks like a 1930s cartoon can cause so much actual, real-world pain. Cuphead might be remembered for its hand-drawn animation and jazzy boss fights, but its co-op mode is a different beast — equal parts exhilarating and soul-destroying. With one player as Cuphead and the other as Mugman, the two are tossed into relentless boss battles and side-scrolling gauntlets with no downtime and even less mercy.

There’s a delicate ballet of dodging bullets, parrying pink objects, and yelling “get me, GET ME!” while floating off-screen as a ghost. The ability to revive a fallen partner with a timely jump adds a layer of risk-reward that often ends in mutual failure and uncontrollable laughter. The chaos is constant, but never unfair. Every mistake feels earned. And every victory — even if it’s after the 23rd try — feels like conquering Everest in tap shoes. For players who want co-op to test friendships and reaction times, this one hits like a well-timed parry.

2 Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime

Neon Panic In A Bubble Ship

Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime
9.0 /10
Released
February 9, 2016

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Fantasy Violence
Platform(s)
PC, PS4, Switch, Xbox One
Powered by

If there’s one game that’s proof of the phrase “communication is key,” it’s Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime . It drops two players into a spherical spaceship shaped like a cosmic hamster wheel and tasks them with flying, shooting, shielding, and not dying while navigating galactic battlefields.

The catch? Each station on the ship only does one thing, and someone has to physically run to it. So, while one person scrambles to man the shield during an ambush, the other is trying to rotate the turret to shoot the swarm of neon crab monsters crawling in from the left. And just when things start to calm down, the entire level flips upside down or turns into a laser maze.

The game’s vibrant aesthetic hides how tense things can get, especially in later stages. Upgrades allow for ship customization, but no amount of firepower helps if one player forgets to man the engine. That’s what makes it so addictive. Each run feels like a barely-controlled disaster, powered by laughter, panic, and occasional shrieking.

1 Overcooked 2

Why Is The Fire Extinguisher On Fire?

Overcooked 2
7 /10
8.8 /10
Released
August 7, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E for Everyone
Developer(s)
Team17, Ghost Town Games
Publisher(s)
Team17
Platform(s)
Switch, PS4, PC, Xbox One, PS5, Xbox Series X, Xbox Series S, Stadia, Amazon Luna
Powered by

Some games bring players together. Overcooked 2 hurls them into a flaming kitchen on a blimp, straps them with a time limit, and then adds a portal that randomly teleports them into traffic. And somehow, it’s still one of the most joyful co-op experiences ever made. Each level drops players into a new culinary disaster zone, where coordination is optional, but chaos is guaranteed. It’s not uncommon for one player to be stuck on a moving platform with all the rice, while the other screams across a gap, holding a dirty plate and a burning pot of soup.

And yet, that’s where the magic happens. Even complete newcomers can jump in, toss an onion, and suddenly find themselves in charge of an interdimensional sushi bar. The sequel builds on everything the first did right, adding online play, dynamic stages, and the kind of environmental hazards OSHA would lose sleep over. The best part? The worse the team is, the more fun the game gets.
